Ask HN: Why isn't WiFi calling totally free?
text:
After the recent Android security issue with Exynos chipsets and WiFi calling ( https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2023/03/critical-vulnerabilities-allow-some-android-phones-to-be-hacked/ ) I took a look at how my mobile provider does WiFi calling.

Vodafone (and many other providers) proudly declare something to the effect of, "There is no extra charge for WiFi calling, the minutes will still count towards your allowance and there won't be a charge for the data against your allowance.".

But if we're not using the cell towers and most of their network (except last mile), and we're providing our own already paid-for data connection... why would WiFi calling count towards _any_ allowance since it incentivises behaviour that reduces costs for telcos?

Is this purely a "They found a way to reduce their costs and still charge us?" or is there more to it?

title: Stripe shut down my account over first customer's payment issue due to 3DS
text:
Yes, Stripe shut down my account because of a single customer's failed payment attempts. The crazy part is that it's neither the business's nor the customer's fault. The sad part is it was supposed to be my first sale.

Allow me to enlighten you about 3DS, Before I share what exactly happened:

As an Indian business using Stripe, all international card payments made to my Stripe account will go through 3D Secure (3DS) authentication.

What is 3DS?

3DS means going through an additional step (2FA) when making a card payment, but in case of a dispute, the liability shifts from the business to the card issuer.

ref: https://support.stripe.com/questions/3d-secure-authentication-for-international-card-payments-to-indian-businesses

Now, here's what happened:

One customer reached out to me to do a promotion on my product.

I sent the customer a payment link.

The customer's payment didn't go through because of the following error:

"3D Secure was completed, but the customer hasn't been verified because the bank does not support 3D Secure, has not set up 3D Secure for the card, or is experiencing an outage. The card network has provided proof of the attempt."

screenshot: https://cln.sh/ZTGrX85T

So the customer tried with other cards but faced the same issue.

Here's the screenshot of the conversation with the customer over email regarding this: https://cln.sh/NGVRg449

When I went back to the Stripe dashboard to see what's going on, I saw a scary orange banner at the top stating: "Your account is under review." I panicked and reached out to support. They sent me this email:

"We recently identified payments on your Stripe account that don’t appear to have been authorized by the customer, meaning that the owner of the card or bank account didn’t consent to these payments. As a precautionary measure, we will no longer accept payments. We’re sorry we can’t be of more help, but these restrictions are firm."

That's it, they blocked the account and can't be of more help. I was not expecting that at all.

I responded that the customer indeed tried to pay but couldn't complete the payment because of some 3DS issue from the bank side. I also attached the screenshot of the conversation I had with the customer.

screenshot: https://cln.sh/yxRc6tmM

I didn't get any reply from the support team after that.

As a second-to-last resort, I reached out to their Twitter support to explain the situation and got the same response:

"Thank you for waiting while we looked into this. We have taken a thorough review of your account and have concluded that we are unable to support your business. We appreciate that this is far from the answer you were hoping for. Unfortunately, we do not have any further information to share. We wish you the best moving forward."

screenshot: https://cln.sh/0cZRgwTh

I was also not expecting that at all.

As a last resort, I reached out to Hacker News now.

Show HN: Hacker News Summarizer (Chrome Extension)
text:
Hey Hacker News community,

We're excited to announce the launch of our new Chrome extension, "Hacker News Summarizer," which uses OpenAI API to summarize articles on Hacker News. It helps you quickly understand the key takeaways without reading the whole article. Plus, no login or confirmation is required to use it! Simply install the extension and click the "summary" link next to "comments" when you want to read an article.

Disclaimer: Not all articles are summarised, or supported but we will change and try to support them later. Additionally, this extension is not affiliated with OpenAI or Hacker News.

Chrome Extension: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/hacker-news-summar...

Try it out today and let us know what you think in the comments below!

Thanks, The Hacker News Summarizer team

title: Ask HN: What is your prediction for a Search Engine for the next 20 years?
text:
With a lot of improvements in the LLM space, I am both excited and concerned. On one hand, giving internet access to ChatGPT may yield good results, but I am not sure about the quality of answers it will provide since it uses Bing under the hood. On the other hand, the internet will soon be flooded with garbage AI content, making it even harder to filter and find good content.

I am curious, what is your prediction for what the search engine will look like in the next 20 years?

Ask HN: Where to find a coach for high-level tech topics?
text:
I did a CS degree 8 years ago and mostly worked in project and product management (often in non-tech companies). But I want to work more with tech-teams and need to freshen up my cloud understanding, API and basic python skills after some informal interviews.

I know coursera, linkedin learning and these online platforms but I struggle with procrastination as well not having someone that can explain it to me in simple words. Optimally I would work together with a coach a few hours a week and discuss specific cases and happy to pay for it.

HN is the community I respect most and I wonder if there is already such a platform to match a good coach or anyone enjoying teaching and is interested in part-time remote coaching on these topics?

Based: Switzerland,Europe (but fine with evening sessions due to timezone difference with the US for example)
